5#ifndef V8_REGEXP_EXPERIMENTAL_EXPERIMENTAL_BYTECODE_H_
6#define V8_REGEXP_EXPERIMENTAL_EXPERIMENTAL_BYTECODE_H_
7
8#include <ios>
9
10#include "src/base/bit-field.h"
11#include "src/base/strings.h"

15// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
16// Definition and semantics of the EXPERIMENTAL bytecode.
17// Background:
18// - Russ Cox's blog post series on regular expression matching, in particular
19// https://swtch.com/~rsc/regexp/regexp2.html
20// - The re2 regular regexp library: https://github.com/google/re2
21//
22// This comment describes the bytecode used by the experimental regexp engine
23// and its abstract semantics in terms of a VM. An implementation of the
24// semantics that avoids exponential runtime can be found in `NfaInterpreter`.
25//
26// The experimental bytecode describes a non-deterministic finite automaton. It
27// runs on a multithreaded virtual machine (VM), i.e. in several threads
28// concurrently. (These "threads" don't need to be actual operating system
29// threads.) Apart from a list of threads, the VM maintains an immutable
30// shared input string which threads can read from. Each thread is given by a
31// program counter (PC, index of the current instruction), a fixed number of
32// registers of indices into the input string, and a monotonically increasing
33// index which represents the current position within the input string.
34//
35// For the precise encoding of the instruction set, see the definition `struct
36// RegExpInstruction` below. Currently we support the following instructions:
37// - CONSUME_RANGE: Check whether the codepoint of the current character is
38// contained in a non-empty closed interval [min, max] specified in the
39// instruction payload. Abort this thread if false, otherwise advance the
40// input position by 1 and continue with the next instruction.
41// - ACCEPT: Stop this thread and signify the end of a match at the current
42// input position.
43// - FORK: If executed by a thread t, spawn a new thread t0 whose register
44// values and input position agree with those of t, but whose PC value is set
45// to the value specified in the instruction payload. The register values of
46// t and t0 agree directly after the FORK, but they can diverge. Thread t
47// continues with the instruction directly after the current FORK
48// instruction.
49// - JMP: Instead of incrementing the PC value after execution of this
50// instruction by 1, set PC of this thread to the value specified in the
51// instruction payload and continue there.
52// - SET_REGISTER_TO_CP: Set a register specified in the paylod to the current
53// position (CP) within the input, then continue with the next instruction.
54// - CLEAR_REGISTER: Clear the register specified in the payload by resetting
55// it to the initial value -1.
56//
57// Special care must be exercised with respect to thread priority. It is
58// possible that more than one thread executes an ACCEPT statement. The output
59// of the program is given by the contents of the matching thread's registers,
60// so this is ambiguous in case of multiple matches. To resolve the ambiguity,
61// every implementation of the VM must output the match that a backtracking
62// implementation would output (i.e. behave the same as Irregexp).
63//
64// A backtracking implementation of the VM maintains a stack of postponed
65// threads. Upon encountering a FORK statement, this VM will create a copy of
66// the current thread, set the copy's PC value according to the instruction
67// payload, and push it to the stack of postponed threads. The VM will then
68// continue execution of the current thread.
69//
70// If at some point a thread t executes a MATCH statement, the VM stops and
71// outputs the registers of t. Postponed threads are discarded. On the other
72// hand, if a thread t is aborted because some input character didn't pass a
73// check, then the VM pops the topmost postponed thread and continues execution
74// with this thread. If there are no postponed threads, then the VM outputs
75// failure, i.e. no matches.
76//
77// Equivalently, we can describe the behavior of the backtracking VM in terms
78// of priority: Threads are linearly ordered by priority, and matches generated
79// by threads with high priority must be preferred over matches generated by
80// threads with low priority, regardless of the chronological order in which
81// matches were found. If a thread t executes a FORK statement and spawns a
82// thread t0, then the priority of t0 is such that the following holds:
83// * t0 < t, i.e. t0 has lower priority than t.
84// * For all threads u such that u != t and u != t0, we have t0 < u iff t < u,
85// i.e. the t0 compares to other threads the same as t.
86// For example, if there are currently 3 threads s, t, u such that s < t < u,
87// then after t executes a fork, the thread priorities will be s < t0 < t < u.
88
89namespace v8 {
90namespace internal {
91
92// Bytecode format.
93// Currently very simple fixed-size: The opcode is encoded in the first 4
94// bytes, the payload takes another 4 bytes.
95struct RegExpInstruction {
96 enum Opcode : int32_t {
97 ACCEPT,
98 ASSERTION,
99 CLEAR_REGISTER,
100 CONSUME_RANGE,
101 FORK,
102 JMP,
103 SET_REGISTER_TO_CP,
104 BEGIN_LOOP,
105 END_LOOP,
106 WRITE_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE,
107 READ_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE,
108 };
109
110 struct Uc16Range {
111 base::uc16 min; // Inclusive.
112 base::uc16 max; // Inclusive.
113 };
114 class ReadLookbehindTablePayload {
115 public:
116 ReadLookbehindTablePayload() = default;
117 ReadLookbehindTablePayload(int32_t lookbehind_index, bool is_positive)
118 : payload_(IsPositive::update(LookbehindIndex::encode(lookbehind_index),
119 is_positive)) {}
120
121 int32_t lookbehind_index() const {
122 return LookbehindIndex::decode(payload_);
123 }
124 bool is_positive() const { return IsPositive::decode(payload_); }
125
126 private:
127 using IsPositive = base::BitField<bool, 0, 1>;
128 using LookbehindIndex = base::BitField<int32_t, 1, 31>;
129 uint32_t payload_;
130 };
131
132 static RegExpInstruction ConsumeRange(base::uc16 min, base::uc16 max) {
133 RegExpInstruction result;
134 result.opcode = CONSUME_RANGE;
135 result.payload.consume_range = Uc16Range{min, max};
136 return result;
137 }
138
139 static RegExpInstruction ConsumeAnyChar() {
140 return ConsumeRange(0x0000, 0xFFFF);
141 }
142
143 static RegExpInstruction Fail() {
144 // This is encoded as the empty CONSUME_RANGE of characters 0xFFFF <= c <=
145 // 0x0000.
146 return ConsumeRange(0xFFFF, 0x0000);
147 }
148
149 static RegExpInstruction Fork(int32_t alt_index) {
150 RegExpInstruction result;
151 result.opcode = FORK;
152 result.payload.pc = alt_index;
153 return result;
154 }
155
156 static RegExpInstruction Jmp(int32_t alt_index) {
157 RegExpInstruction result;
158 result.opcode = JMP;
159 result.payload.pc = alt_index;
160 return result;
161 }
162
163 static RegExpInstruction Accept() {
164 RegExpInstruction result;
165 result.opcode = ACCEPT;
166 return result;
167 }
168
169 static RegExpInstruction SetRegisterToCp(int32_t register_index) {
170 RegExpInstruction result;
171 result.opcode = SET_REGISTER_TO_CP;
172 result.payload.register_index = register_index;
173 return result;
174 }
175
176 static RegExpInstruction ClearRegister(int32_t register_index) {
177 RegExpInstruction result;
178 result.opcode = CLEAR_REGISTER;
179 result.payload.register_index = register_index;
180 return result;
181 }
182
183 static RegExpInstruction Assertion(RegExpAssertion::Type t) {
184 RegExpInstruction result;
185 result.opcode = ASSERTION;
186 result.payload.assertion_type = t;
187 return result;
188 }
189
190 static RegExpInstruction BeginLoop() {
191 RegExpInstruction result;
192 result.opcode = BEGIN_LOOP;
193 return result;
194 }
195
196 static RegExpInstruction EndLoop() {
197 RegExpInstruction result;
198 result.opcode = END_LOOP;
199 return result;
200 }
201
202 static RegExpInstruction WriteLookTable(int32_t index) {
203 RegExpInstruction result;
204 result.opcode = WRITE_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE;
205 result.payload.looktable_index = index;
206 return result;
207 }
208
209 static RegExpInstruction ReadLookTable(int32_t index, bool is_positive) {
210 RegExpInstruction result;
211 result.opcode = READ_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE;
212
213 result.payload.read_lookbehind =
214 ReadLookbehindTablePayload(index, is_positive);
215 return result;
216 }
217
218 Opcode opcode;
219 union {
220 // Payload of CONSUME_RANGE:
221 Uc16Range consume_range;
222 // Payload of FORK and JMP, the next/forked program counter (pc):
223 int32_t pc;
224 // Payload of SET_REGISTER_TO_CP and CLEAR_REGISTER:
225 int32_t register_index;
226 // Payload of ASSERTION:
227 RegExpAssertion::Type assertion_type;
228 // Payload of WRITE_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE:
229 int32_t looktable_index;
230 // Payload of READ_LOOKBEHIND_TABLE:
231 ReadLookbehindTablePayload read_lookbehind;
232 } payload;
233 static_assert(sizeof(payload) == 4);
234};
235static_assert(sizeof(RegExpInstruction) == 8);
236// TODO(mbid,v8:10765): This is rather wasteful. We can fit the opcode in 2-3
237// bits, so the remaining 29/30 bits can be used as payload. Problem: The
238// payload of CONSUME_RANGE consists of two 16-bit values `min` and `max`, so
239// this wouldn't fit. We could encode the payload of a CONSUME_RANGE
240// instruction by the start of the interval and its length instead, and then
241// only allows lengths that fit into 14/13 bits. A longer range can then be
242// encoded as a disjunction of smaller ranges.
243//
244// Another thought: CONSUME_RANGEs are only valid if the payloads are such that
245// min <= max. Thus there are
246//
247// 2^16 + 2^16 - 1 + ... + 1
248// = 2^16 * (2^16 + 1) / 2
249// = 2^31 + 2^15
250//
251// valid payloads for a CONSUME_RANGE instruction. If we want to fit
252// instructions into 4 bytes, we would still have almost 2^31 instructions left
253// over if we encode everything as tight as possible. For example, we could
254// use another 2^29 values for JMP, another 2^29 for FORK, 1 value for ACCEPT,
255// and then still have almost 2^30 instructions left over for something like
256// zero-width assertions and captures.
257
258std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, const RegExpInstruction& inst);
259std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os,
260 base::Vector<const RegExpInstruction> insts);
261
262} // namespace internal
263} // namespace v8
264
265#endif // V8_REGEXP_EXPERIMENTAL_EXPERIMENTAL_BYTECODE_H_
